question: <image 1> Which of the following was another common criticism of Andrew Carnegie?
options: ['As an immigrant, Carnegie had no right to own controlling interests in major American industries.', 'Carnegie did nothing to prevent the use of violence against his workers when they asked for better wages and working conditions.', 'Carnegie was seen as the epitome of American success, but he was not even the richest man in America.', "Too much of Carnegie's philanthropic efforts were concentrated on his homeland of Scotland, denying Americans the benefits of his charity."]
description: The image is a political cartoon titled "Forty-Millionaire Carnegie in his Great Double Role," published in The Saturday Globe on July 9, 1892. The cartoon depicts Andrew Carnegie in two contrasting roles. On one side, he is shown as a tight-fisted employer, reducing wages by 20 percent, as indicated by a sign he holds. On the other side, he is depicted as a philanthropist, giving away $5,000 from a chest labeled with a dollar sign. The cartoon suggests that Carnegie reduces wages so that he can play the role of a philanthropist and give away libraries, etc. The scene includes workers reacting to both sides of Carnegie's actions, with some appearing distressed over the wage reduction and others reaching out for the charitable donation. The overall message of the cartoon criticizes Carnegie for his dual nature as both a harsh employer and a generous philanthropist.
